# to generate content with a simple prompt.

Our first example demonstrates how to use the Gemini API
to generate content with a simple prompt.

code_segments.code: from google import genai

# Best practice: store your API key in an environment variable
# and load it from there.
code_segments.annotation:
Best practice: store your API key in an environment variable
and load it from there.

code_segments.code:
client = genai.Client(api_key="YOUR_API_KEY")

response = client.models.generate_content(
    model="gemini-2.0-flash", contents="Explain how AI works in a few words"
)
print(response.text)
code_segments.display_code:
client = genai.Client(api_key="YOUR_API_KEY")

It processes information through neural networks that mimic human brain connections, identifying features and relationships to perform tasks like recognition, prediction, and generation.

examples.title: Streaming text
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use the Gemini API to generate text content and stream the output.

code_segments.code: # Import the Gemini API
code_segments.annotation: Import the Gemini API

code_segments.code: from google import genai
# Initialize the Gemini client with your API key
code_segments.annotation: Initialize the Gemini client with your API key

code_segments.code: client = genai.Client(api_key="YOUR_API_KEY")
# Call the API to generate content in streaming mode
code_segments.annotation: Call the API to generate content in streaming mode

code_segments.code:
response = client.models.generate_content_stream(
    model="gemini-2.0-flash",
    contents=["Explain how AI works"]
)
code_segments.display_code:
response = client.models.generate_content_stream(
    model="gemini-2.0-flash",
    contents=["Explain how AI works"]
)

code_segments.code: # Iterate over the stream of responses and print each chunk of text
code_segments.annotation: Iterate over the stream of responses and print each chunk of text

code_segments.code:
for chunk in response:
    print(chunk.text, end="")
code_segments.display_code:
for chunk in response:
    print(chunk.text, end="")

shell_segments.explanation: First, install the Google Generative AI library
Then run the program with Python
shell_segments.output: AI, or Artificial Intelligence, is a broad field of computer science focused on creating machines capable of performing tasks that typically require human intelligence. It involves developing algorithms and models that enable computers to learn from data, reason, solve problems, understand natural language, perceive their environment, and make decisions.

examples.title: System prompt
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use system instructions to guide the model's behavior.

code_segments.code: # Import the Gemini API
code_segments.annotation: Import the Gemini API

code_segments.code:
from google import genai
from google.genai import types
code_segments.display_code:
from google import genai
from google.genai import types

code_segments.code: # Initialize the Gemini client with your API key
code_segments.annotation: Initialize the Gemini client with your API key

code_segments.code: client = genai.Client(api_key="YOUR_API_KEY")

# Configure the model with system instructions
# These instructions tell the model to act as a pirate
code_segments.annotation:
Configure the model with system instructions
These instructions tell the model to act as a pirate

code_segments.code:
response = client.models.generate_content(
    model="gemini-2.0-flash",
    config=types.GenerateContentConfig(
        system_instruction="You are a pirate.  Answer all questions like a pirate."),
    contents="Hello there"
)
code_segments.display_code:
response = client.models.generate_content(
    model="gemini-2.0-flash",
    config=types.GenerateContentConfig(
        system_instruction="You are a pirate.  Answer all questions like a pirate."),
    contents="Hello there"
)

code_segments.code: # Print the model's response
code_segments.annotation: Print the model's response

code_segments.code: print(response.text)

shell_segments.explanation: First, install the Google Generative AI library
Then run the program with Python

examples.title: Image question answering
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use the Gemini API to analyze or understand images of cats, including using image URLs and base64 encoding.

code_segments.code: # Import necessary libraries
code_segments.annotation: Import necessary libraries

code_segments.code:
from google import genai
from google.genai import types
import requests
import base64
code_segments.display_code:
from google import genai
from google.genai import types
import requests
import base64

code_segments.code: # Replace with your Gemini API key
code_segments.annotation: Replace with your Gemini API key

code_segments.code: client = genai.Client(api_key="YOUR_API_KEY")

# We'll start by using an image URL.
# Load an image of a cat from a URL
code_segments.annotation:
We'll start by using an image URL.
Load an image of a cat from a URL

code_segments.code:
image_url = "https://cataas.com/cat"
image_response = requests.get(image_url)
image_content = image_response.content
# Ask Gemini about the cat in the image
code_segments.annotation: Ask Gemini about the cat in the image

code_segments.code:
response = client.models.generate_content(
    model="gemini-2.0-flash",
    contents=["What breed of cat is this?", types.Part.from_bytes(data=image_content, mime_type="image/jpeg")]
)

print("Response from URL Image:\n", response.text)
code_segments.display_code:
response = client.models.generate_content(
    model="gemini-2.0-flash",
    contents=["What breed of cat is this?", types.Part.from_bytes(data=image_content, mime_type="image/jpeg")]
)

print("Response from URL Image:\n", response.text)

code_segments.code:
# Now we'll use a local image file.
# Load a local image of a cat and encode it as Base64
code_segments.annotation:
Now we'll use a local image file.
Load a local image of a cat and encode it as Base64

code_segments.code:
with open("cat.jpg", "rb") as image_file:
    encoded_string = base64.b64encode(image_file.read())
code_segments.display_code:
with open("cat.jpg", "rb") as image_file:
    encoded_string = base64.b64encode(image_file.read())

code_segments.code: # Ensure the encoded string is a string
code_segments.annotation: Ensure the encoded string is a string

code_segments.code: encoded_string = encoded_string.decode('utf-8')
# Ask Gemini a question about the cat, providing the image as a Base64 string
code_segments.annotation: Ask Gemini a question about the cat, providing the image as a Base64 string

code_segments.code:
response = client.models.generate_content(
    model="gemini-2.0-flash",
    contents=["Is this cat fluffy?", types.Part.from_bytes(data=base64.b64decode(encoded_string), mime_type="image/jpeg")]
)

print("\nResponse from Base64 Image:\n", response.text)
code_segments.display_code:
response = client.models.generate_content(
    model="gemini-2.0-flash",
    contents=["Is this cat fluffy?", types.Part.from_bytes(data=base64.b64decode(encoded_string), mime_type="image/jpeg")]
)

print("\nResponse from Base64 Image:\n", response.text)

shell_segments.explanation: First, install the Google Generative AI library and requests
Download an example cat image (replace with your own if needed)
Then run the program with Python
shell_segments.output:
Response from URL Image:
 This looks like a British Shorthair cat.

examples.title: Image generation (Gemini and Imagen)
examples.description: This example demonstrates generating images using both Gemini 2.0 Flash and Imagen 3 models, focusing on cat-related prompts.

code_segments.code: # Import necessary libraries. Make sure Pillow is installed!
code_segments.annotation: Import necessary libraries. Make sure Pillow is installed!

code_segments.code:
from google import genai
from google.genai import types
from PIL import Image
from io import BytesIO
code_segments.display_code:
from google import genai
from google.genai import types
from PIL import Image
from io import BytesIO

code_segments.code: # Initialize the Gemini client with your API key
code_segments.annotation: Initialize the Gemini client with your API key

code_segments.code: client = genai.Client(api_key="YOUR_API_KEY")

# We start by using Gemini 2.0 Flash for image generation.
# Demonstrates generating an image and associated text using Gemini 2.0 Flash.
code_segments.annotation:
We start by using Gemini 2.0 Flash for image generation.
Demonstrates generating an image and associated text using Gemini 2.0 Flash.

code_segments.code:
contents = (
    "Hi, can you create a 3D rendered image of a cat wearing a wizard hat, "
    "casting a spell in a magical forest?"
)

response = client.models.generate_content(
    model="gemini-2.0-flash-exp-image-generation",
    contents=contents,
    config=types.GenerateContentConfig(response_modalities=["Text", "Image"]),
)
code_segments.display_code:
contents = (
    "Hi, can you create a 3D rendered image of a cat wearing a wizard hat, "
    "casting a spell in a magical forest?"
)

response = client.models.generate_content(
    model="gemini-2.0-flash-exp-image-generation",
    contents=contents,
    config=types.GenerateContentConfig(response_modalities=["Text", "Image"]),
)

code_segments.code: # Save the image to a file and display it
code_segments.annotation: Save the image to a file and display it

code_segments.code:
# Now we use Imagen 3 for image generation.
# Demonstrates generating multiple high-quality images of cats using Imagen 3.
# Imagen 3 is only available on the Paid Tier and always includes a SynthID watermark.
code_segments.annotation:
Now we use Imagen 3 for image generation.
Demonstrates generating multiple high-quality images of cats using Imagen 3.
Imagen 3 is only available on the Paid Tier and always includes a SynthID watermark.

code_segments.code:
response = client.models.generate_images(
    model="imagen-3.0-generate-002",
    prompt="A photorealistic image of a cat astronaut floating in space",
    config=types.GenerateImagesConfig(number_of_images=2),
)
code_segments.display_code:
response = client.models.generate_images(
    model="imagen-3.0-generate-002",
    prompt="A photorealistic image of a cat astronaut floating in space",
    config=types.GenerateImagesConfig(number_of_images=2),
)

code_segments.code: # Save the images to files and display them
code_segments.annotation: Save the images to files and display them

code_segments.code:
for i, generated_image in enumerate(response.generated_images):
    image = Image.open(BytesIO(generated_image.image.image_bytes))
    image.save(f"imagen-cat-astronaut-{i+1}.png")
    image.show()
code_segments.display_code:
for i, generated_image in enumerate(response.generated_images):
    image = Image.open(BytesIO(generated_image.image.image_bytes))
    image.save(f"imagen-cat-astronaut-{i+1}.png")
    image.show()

shell_segments.explanation: First, install the Google Generative AI library
Then run the program with Python
shell_segments.output:
# Expected output (will vary based on the model):
# (Text describing the cat wizard image from Gemini 2.0 Flash)
# (Two image windows will open, displaying the generated cat astronaut images from Imagen 3)
# Image saved as gemini-cat-wizard.png
# (Two image windows will open, displaying the generated cat astronaut images from Imagen 3)

examples.title: Edit an image
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to edit an existing image of a cat to add a hat using the Gemini API.

code_segments.code: # Import necessary libraries. Make sure Pillow is installed!
code_segments.annotation: Import necessary libraries. Make sure Pillow is installed!

from google import genai
from google.genai import types

from google.genai import types

import requests

# Download the cat image from cataas.com
code_segments.annotation: Download the cat image from cataas.com

response = requests.get(image_url)
cat_image = Image.open(BytesIO(response.content))
# Prepare a prompt.
code_segments.annotation: Prepare a prompt.

code_segments.code: text_prompt = "Please add a stylish top hat to this cat."
code_segments.display_code: text_prompt = "Please add a stylish top hat to this cat."

code_segments.annotation: Generate content with the Gemini API

code_segments.code:
model = "gemini-2.0-flash-exp-image-generation"
response = client.models.generate_content(
    model=model,
    contents=[text_prompt, cat_image],
    config=types.GenerateContentConfig(response_modalities=["Text", "Image"]),
)
code_segments.display_code:

response = client.models.generate_content(
    model=model,
    contents=[text_prompt, cat_image],
    config=types.GenerateContentConfig(response_modalities=["Text", "Image"]),
)

code_segments.code: # Process the response. Retry if you get a 500 error.

code_segments.annotation: The data is provided as raw bytes, not base64-encoded

code_segments.code:
image = Image.open(BytesIO(part.inline_data.data))
        image.save("cat_with_hat.png")

examples.title: Bounding boxes
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use the Gemini API to detect an object (a cat) in an image and retrieve its bounding box coordinates.

code_segments.code: # Import necessary libraries. Make sure Pillow is installed!
code_segments.annotation: Import necessary libraries. Make sure Pillow is installed!

code_segments.code:
from google import genai
import requests
from PIL import Image
from io import BytesIO
code_segments.display_code:
from google import genai
import requests
from PIL import Image
from io import BytesIO

code_segments.code: # Initialize the Gemini client with your API key
code_segments.annotation: Initialize the Gemini client with your API key

code_segments.code: client = genai.Client(api_key="YOUR_API_KEY")
# Specify the prompt, asking for a bounding box around the cat
code_segments.annotation: Specify the prompt, asking for a bounding box around the cat

code_segments.code:
prompt = (
    "Return a bounding box for the cat in this image "
    "in [ymin, xmin, ymax, xmax] format."
)
code_segments.display_code:
prompt = (
    "Return a bounding box for the cat in this image "
    "in [ymin, xmin, ymax, xmax] format."
)

code_segments.code: # Download the cat image from cataas.com
code_segments.annotation: Download the cat image from cataas.com

code_segments.code:
image_url = "https://cataas.com/cat"
response = requests.get(image_url)
cat_image = Image.open(BytesIO(response.content))
# Call the Gemini API to generate content with the image and prompt
code_segments.annotation: Call the Gemini API to generate content with the image and prompt

code_segments.code: # Print the response text, which will contain the bounding box coordinates
code_segments.annotation: Print the response text, which will contain the bounding box coordinates

code_segments.code: print(response.text)

#
# Normalize Coordinates
# The model returns bounding box coordinates in the format [y_min, x_min, y_max, x_max].
# To convert these normalized coordinates to the pixel coordinates of your original image, follow these steps:
# 1. Divide each output coordinate by 1000.
# 2. Multiply the x-coordinates by the original image width.
# 3. Multiply the y-coordinates by the original image height.
#
# Example Calculation (assuming the model returns [200, 300, 700, 800] and the image is 1000x800):
code_segments.annotation:
Normalize Coordinates
The model returns bounding box coordinates in the format [y_min, x_min, y_max, x_max].
To convert these normalized coordinates to the pixel coordinates of your original image, follow these steps:
1. Divide each output coordinate by 1000.
2. Multiply the x-coordinates by the original image width.
3. Multiply the y-coordinates by the original image height.

Example Calculation (assuming the model returns [200, 300, 700, 800] and the image is 1000x800):

examples.title: Image segmentation
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use the Gemini API to perform image segmentation on a picture of a cat.

code_segments.code: # Import the Gemini API and necessary libraries. Make sure Pillow is installed!
code_segments.annotation: Import the Gemini API and necessary libraries. Make sure Pillow is installed!

code_segments.code:
from google import genai
import os
import requests
from PIL import Image
from io import BytesIO
import json
import base64
code_segments.display_code:
from google import genai
import os
import requests
from PIL import Image
from io import BytesIO
import json
import base64

code_segments.code: # Initialize the Gemini client with your API key
code_segments.annotation: Initialize the Gemini client with your API key

code_segments.code: client = genai.Client(api_key=os.getenv("GEMINI_API_KEY"))
# Define the prompt for image segmentation, focusing on cats
code_segments.annotation: Define the prompt for image segmentation, focusing on cats

code_segments.code:
prompt = """
Give the segmentation masks for the cat in the image.
Output a JSON list of segmentation masks where each entry contains the 2D
bounding box in the key \"box_2d\", the segmentation mask in key \"mask\", and
the text label in the key \"label\". Use descriptive labels.
"""
code_segments.display_code:
prompt = """
Give the segmentation masks for the cat in the image.
Output a JSON list of segmentation masks where each entry contains the 2D
bounding box in the key \"box_2d\", the segmentation mask in key \"mask\", and
the text label in the key \"label\". Use descriptive labels.
"""

code_segments.code: # Download the cat image from cataas.com
code_segments.annotation: Download the cat image from cataas.com

code_segments.code:
image_url = "https://cataas.com/cat"
response = requests.get(image_url)
cat_image = Image.open(BytesIO(response.content))
# Save the original image
code_segments.annotation: Save the original image

code_segments.code:
original_filename = f"cat_original.png"
cat_image.save(original_filename)
print(f"Original image saved as: {original_filename}")
code_segments.display_code:
original_filename = f"cat_original.png"
cat_image.save(original_filename)
print(f"Original image saved as: {original_filename}")

code_segments.code: # Call the Gemini API to generate content with the image and prompt
code_segments.annotation: Call the Gemini API to generate content with the image and prompt

code_segments.code: # Print the response containing segmentation information.
code_segments.annotation: Print the response containing segmentation information.

code_segments.code: print(response.text)

# Display and save the overlaid mask.
# Extract the JSON part from the response (it might be wrapped in markdown)
code_segments.annotation:
Display and save the overlaid mask.
Extract the JSON part from the response (it might be wrapped in markdown)

code_segments.code: # Parse JSON data
code_segments.annotation: Parse JSON data

code_segments.code: mask_data = json.loads(json_str)
# Get the first mask. This assumes a mask was returned.
code_segments.annotation: Get the first mask. This assumes a mask was returned.

code_segments.code: first_mask = mask_data[0]
# Extract base64 encoded mask
code_segments.annotation: Extract base64 encoded mask

code_segments.code: # Decode and load the mask image
code_segments.annotation: Decode and load the mask image

code_segments.code:
mask_bytes = base64.b64decode(mask_base64)
mask_image = Image.open(BytesIO(mask_bytes))
# Convert images to RGBA
code_segments.annotation: Convert images to RGBA

code_segments.code:
cat_image = cat_image.convert("RGBA")
mask_image = mask_image.convert("L")  # Convert mask to grayscale
code_segments.display_code:
cat_image = cat_image.convert("RGBA")
mask_image = mask_image.convert("L")  # Convert mask to grayscale

code_segments.code: # Create a bright colored overlay (bright pink)
code_segments.annotation: Create a bright colored overlay (bright pink)

code_segments.code:
# Use the mask to determine where to apply the color.
# We need the mask as an alpha channel
code_segments.annotation:
Use the mask to determine where to apply the color.
We need the mask as an alpha channel

code_segments.code: overlay.putalpha(mask_image)
# Resize the overlay to match the original image if needed
code_segments.annotation: Resize the overlay to match the original image if needed

code_segments.code:
if overlay.size != cat_image.size:
    overlay = overlay.resize(cat_image.size)
# Overlay the colored mask on the original image. Save both images.
code_segments.annotation: Overlay the colored mask on the original image. Save both images.

code_segments.code:
result = Image.alpha_composite(cat_image, overlay)

mask_filename = f"cat_mask.png"
mask_image.save(mask_filename)

merged_filename = f"cat_with_mask.png"
result.save(merged_filename)
code_segments.display_code:
result = Image.alpha_composite(cat_image, overlay)

mask_filename = f"cat_mask.png"
mask_image.save(mask_filename)

merged_filename = f"cat_with_mask.png"
result.save(merged_filename)

examples.title: Audio question answering
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to ask a question about the content of an audio file using the Gemini API.

code_segments.code: # Import the necessary libraries
code_segments.annotation: Import the necessary libraries

code_segments.code:
from google import genai
from google.genai import types
import requests
import os
code_segments.display_code:
from google import genai
from google.genai import types
import requests
import os

code_segments.code: # Replace with your actual API key
code_segments.annotation: Replace with your actual API key

code_segments.code: client = genai.Client(api_key=os.getenv("GEMINI_API_KEY"))
# Define a descriptive User-Agent following Wikimedia's policy
code_segments.annotation: Define a descriptive User-Agent following Wikimedia's policy

code_segments.code: user_agent = "GeminiByExample/1.0 (https://github.com/strickvl/geminibyexample; contact@example.org) python-requests/2.0"
# Download the audio file from the URL
code_segments.annotation: Download the audio file from the URL

code_segments.code:
url = "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1f/%22DayBreak%22_with_Jay_Young_on_the_USA_Radio_Network.ogg"
headers = {"User-Agent": user_agent}
response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
response.raise_for_status()  # Raise an exception for bad status codes
code_segments.display_code:
url = "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1f/%22DayBreak%22_with_Jay_Young_on_the_USA_Radio_Network.ogg"
headers = {"User-Agent": user_agent}
response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
response.raise_for_status()  # Raise an exception for bad status codes

code_segments.code:
# Save the content to a variable
# Note: If your audio file is larger than 20MB, you should use the File API to upload the file first.
# The File API allows you to upload larger files and then reference them in your requests.
code_segments.annotation:
Save the content to a variable
Note: If your audio file is larger than 20MB, you should use the File API to upload the file first.
The File API allows you to upload larger files and then reference them in your requests.

code_segments.code: audio_bytes = response.content
# You can now pass that audio file along with the prompt to Gemini
code_segments.annotation: You can now pass that audio file along with the prompt to Gemini

code_segments.code:
response = client.models.generate_content(
    model="gemini-2.0-flash",
    contents=[
        "What is the main topic of this audio?",
        types.Part.from_bytes(
            data=audio_bytes,
            mime_type="audio/ogg",
        ),
    ],
)

print(response.text)
code_segments.display_code:
response = client.models.generate_content(
    model="gemini-2.0-flash",
    contents=[
        "What is the main topic of this audio?",
        types.Part.from_bytes(
            data=audio_bytes,
            mime_type="audio/ogg",
        ),
    ],
)

print(response.text)

Then run the program with Python

from google.genai import types

# Define a descriptive User-Agent following Wikimedia's policy

# Download the audio file from the URL

shell_segments.output: We're joined once again by our travel expert and also author of America's Top Roller Coasters and Amusement Parks, Pete Trabucco. Good morning and welcome back to Daybreak USA. Well, thanks for having me on. examples.title: Audio summarization
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to summarize the content of an audio file using the Gemini API.

code_segments.code: # Import the necessary libraries
code_segments.annotation: Import the necessary libraries

code_segments.code:
from google import genai
from google.genai import types
import requests
import os
code_segments.display_code:
from google import genai
from google.genai import types
import requests
import os

code_segments.code: # Replace with your actual API key
code_segments.annotation: Replace with your actual API key

code_segments.code: client = genai.Client(api_key=os.getenv("GEMINI_API_KEY"))
# Define a descriptive User-Agent following Wikimedia's policy
code_segments.annotation: Define a descriptive User-Agent following Wikimedia's policy

code_segments.code: user_agent = "GeminiByExample/1.0 (https://github.com/strickvl/geminibyexample; contact@example.org) python-requests/2.0"
# Download the audio file from the URL
code_segments.annotation: Download the audio file from the URL

code_segments.code:
url = "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1f/%22DayBreak%22_with_Jay_Young_on_the_USA_Radio_Network.ogg"
headers = {"User-Agent": user_agent}
response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
response.raise_for_status()  # Raise an exception for bad status codes
code_segments.display_code:
url = "https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1f/%22DayBreak%22_with_Jay_Young_on_the_USA_Radio_Network.ogg"
headers = {"User-Agent": user_agent}
response = requests.get(url, headers=headers)
response.raise_for_status()  # Raise an exception for bad status codes

code_segments.code:
# Save the content to a variable
# Note: If your audio file is larger than 20MB, you should use the File API to upload the file first.
# The File API allows you to upload larger files and then reference them in your requests.
code_segments.annotation:
Save the content to a variable
Note: If your audio file is larger than 20MB, you should use the File API to upload the file first.
The File API allows you to upload larger files and then reference them in your requests.

code_segments.code: audio_bytes = response.content
# You can now pass that audio file along with the prompt to Gemini
code_segments.annotation: You can now pass that audio file along with the prompt to Gemini

code_segments.code:
response = client.models.generate_content(
    model="gemini-2.0-flash",
    contents=[
        "What is this audio about?",
        types.Part.from_bytes(
            data=audio_bytes,
            mime_type="audio/ogg",
        ),
    ],
)

print(response.text)
code_segments.display_code:
response = client.models.generate_content(
    model="gemini-2.0-flash",
    contents=[
        "What is this audio about?",
        types.Part.from_bytes(
            data=audio_bytes,
            mime_type="audio/ogg",
        ),
    ],
)

print(response.text)

shell_segments.explanation: First, install the Google Generative AI library and requests
Then run the program with Python
shell_segments.output:
This audio is about travel tips, particularly what to do in the event of a disaster while on vacation.
The speaker emphasizes the importance of staying informed about the destination, traveling with a buddy,
having a plan in place, and investing in travel insurance. They also mention the importance of connecting
with home base and knowing the location of the American Red Cross in case of emergencies.
